ai.summary: A challenging 21.1 km hike along a rugged UK upland route, featuring long ascents, exposed ridgelines, and expansive views.
ai.terrain_summary: Rugged upland ridge with grassy slopes, exposed rock on sections, heather moorland, and occasional woodland. Footing can be uneven and boggy in places; expect long climbs and some scrambling.
ai.safety_notes: This is a long, strenuous day hike. Check weather forecasts and be prepared for rapid condition changes. Carry a map and compass (or GPS), stay on marked paths, and tell someone your plan. Wear sturdy waterproof boots, bring layered clothing, sufficient water and energy snacks, a whistle, and a basic first aid kit. In exposed sections, high winds and poor visibility are possible; ensure you have navigation aids and consider starting early to ensure daylight.
recommended_gear: Sturdy hiking boots with good ankle support
Water and high-energy snacks (2–3 liters depending on conditions)
Layered clothing plus a waterproof/windproof outer layer
Hat and gloves for cold or windy weather
Map and compass (or GPS) and a fully charged phone with offline maps
ai.best_seasons: Spring, Summer, and early Autumn are best for this hike due to milder weather and longer daylight. Winter conditions can be harsh with strong winds and reduced visibility.
